Analyze a Programming Project as a Citations Network

vignette_analyse_citations_network_from_project.Rmd

This vignette give a basic understanding of the citations.network returned within a list by codexplor::get_doc_network_from_project.

Overview

codexplor::get_doc_network_from_project :

  1. compute a corpus.list as it is returned by codexplor::construct_corpus (see vignette of construct_corpus)
  2. and add a new data.frame with additional classes citations.network and internal.dependencies, as the edgelist of a network of the functions defined within the files of the corpus (see the vignette of the citations.network data.frame).

In such a citations.network of internal.dependencies, links start from the programming file that calls a function and point to the programming file where the function is defined.

Example

Given folders path(s) and/or github repo(s), compute a citations network of the internal dependencies with 

require(codexplor)
net <- get_doc_network_from_project(
  repos =  c("tidyverse/stringr"))
        # by default, codexplor deal with R project

get_networkd3_from_igraph(net$internal.dependencies)
        # Return an interactive dataviz' from networkD3

By default, get_networkd3_from_igraph will colorize the nodes accordingly to their indegrees. This reveal the local dependencies of the programming project (i.e. functions used by others files of the project).

.

(codexplor functions network is truncated)

For example, the most-common local dependency inside the tidyverse/stringr repo are modifiers.R compat-types-check.R. Next, there is other text-mining metrics that will give us insights about these files, e.g., one should verify that the local complexity of this compat-types-check.R file is keep to a ‘trivial’ level.

Playing with the parameters of get_networkd3_from_igraph will reveal others insights, e.g., you should try to color nodes accordingly to their outdegrees, in order to reveal the high-level files of the project.
